Byzantine-Resilient Secure Federated Learning

Jinhyun So, Başak Güler, A. Salman Avestimehr Jinhyun So is with the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Southern California, Los Angeles, CA, 90089 USA (e-mail: jinhyuns@usc.edu). Başak Güler is with the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of California, Riverside, CA, 92521 USA (email: bguler@ece.ucr.edu). A. Salman Avestimehr is with the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Southern California, Los Angeles, CA, 90089 USA (e-mail: avestimehr@ee.usc.edu). This work is published in Journal on Selected Areas in Communications [1].
Abstract

Secure federated learning is a privacy-preserving framework to improve machine learning models by training over large volumes of data collected by mobile users. This is achieved through an iterative process where, at each iteration, users update a global model using their local datasets. Each user then masks its local update via random keys, and the masked models are aggregated at a central server to compute the global model for the next iteration. As the local updates are protected by random masks, the server cannot observe their true values. This presents a major challenge for the resilience of the model against adversarial (Byzantine) users, who can manipulate the global model by modifying their local updates or datasets. Towards addressing this challenge, this paper presents the first single-server Byzantine-resilient secure aggregation framework (BREA) for secure federated learning. BREA is based on an integrated stochastic quantization, verifiable outlier detection, and secure model aggregation approach to guarantee Byzantine-resilience, privacy, and convergence simultaneously. We provide theoretical convergence and privacy guarantees and characterize the fundamental trade-offs in terms of the network size, user dropouts, and privacy protection. Our experiments demonstrate convergence in the presence of Byzantine users, and comparable accuracy to conventional federated learning benchmarks.

Index Terms:
Federated learning, privacy-preserving machine learning, Byzantine-resilience, distributed training in mobile networks.

I Introduction

Federated learning is a distributed training framework that has received significant interest in the recent years, by allowing machine learning models to be trained over the vast amount of data collected by mobile devices [2, 3]. In this framework, training is coordinated by a central server who maintains a global model, which is updated by the mobile users through an iterative process. At each iteration, the server sends the current version of the global model to the mobile devices, who update it using their local data and create a local update. The server then aggregates the local updates of the users and updates the global model for the next iteration [2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9].

Security and privacy considerations of distributed learning are mainly focused around two seemingly separate directions: 1) ensuring robustness of the global model against adversarial manipulations and 2) protecting the privacy of individual users. The first direction aims at ensuring that the trained model is robust against Byzantine faults that may occur in the training data or during protocol execution. These faults may result either from an adversarial user who can manipulate the training data or the information exchanged during the protocol, or due to device malfunctioning. Notably, it has been shown that even a single Byzantine fault can significantly alter the trained model [10]. The primary approach for defending against Byzantine faults is by comparing the local updates received from different users and removing the outliers at the server [10, 11, 12, 13, 14]. Doing so, however, requires the server to learn the true values of the local updates of each individual user. The second direction aims at protecting the privacy of the individual users, by keeping each local update private from the server and the other users participating in the protocol [3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8]. This is achieved through what is known as a secure aggregation protocol [3]. In this protocol, each user masks its local update through additive secret sharing using private and pairwise random keys before sending it to the server. Once the masked models are aggregated at the server, the additional randomness cancels out and the server learns the aggregate of all user models. At the end of the protocol, the server learns no information about the individual models beyond the aggregated model, as they are masked by the random keys unknown to the server. In contrast, conventional distributed training frameworks that perform gradient aggregation and model updates using the true values of the gradients may reveal extensive information about the local datasets of the users, as shown in [15, 16, 17].

This presents a major challenge in developing a Byzantine-resilient, and at the same time, privacy-preserving federated learning framework. On the one hand, robustness against Byzantine faults requires the server to obtain the individual model updates in the clear, to be able to compare the updates from different users with each other and remove the outliers. On the other hand, protecting user privacy requires each individual model to be masked with random keys, as a result, the server only observes the masked model, which appears as a uniformly random vector that could correspond to any point in the parameter space. Our goal is to reconcile these two critical directions. In particular, we want to address the following question, “How can one make federated learning protocols robust against Byzantine adversaries while preserving the privacy of individual users?”.

In this paper, we propose the first single-server Byzantine-resilient secure aggregation framework, BREA, towards addressing this problem. Our framework is built on the following main principles. Given a network of N𝑁N mobile users with up to A𝐴A adversaries, each user initially secret shares its local update with the other users, through a verifiable secret sharing protocol [18]. However, doing so requires the local updates to be masked by uniformly random vectors in a finite field [19], whereas the model updates during training are performed in the domain of real numbers. In order to handle this problem, BREA utilizes stochastic quantization to transfer the local updates from the real domain into a finite field.

Verifiable secret sharing allows the users to perform consistency checks to validate the secret shares and ensure that every user follows the protocol. However, a malicious user can still manipulate the global model by modifying its local update or private dataset. BREA handles such attacks through a robust gradient descent approach, enabled by secure computations over the secret shares of the local updates. To do so, each user locally computes the pairwise distances between the secret shares of the local updates belonging to other users, and sends the computation results to the server. Since these computations are carried out using the secret shares, users do not learn the true values of the local updates belonging to other users.

In the final phase, the server collects the computation results from a sufficient number of users, recovers the pairwise distances between the local updates, and performs user selection for model aggregation. The user selection protocol is based on a distance-based outlier removal mechanism [10], to remove the effect of potential adversaries and to ensure that the selected models are sufficiently close to an unbiased gradient estimator. After the user selection phase, the secret shares of the models belonging to the selected users are aggregated locally by the mobile users. The server then gathers the secure computation results from the users, reconstructs the true value of the aggregate of the selected user models, and updates the global model. Our framework guarantees the privacy of individual user models, in particular, the server learns no information about the local updates, beyond their aggregated value and the pairwise distances.

In our theoretical analysis, we demonstrate provable convergence guarantees for the model and robustness guarantees against Byzantine adversaries. We then identify the theoretical performance limits in terms of the fundamental trade-offs between the network size, user dropouts, number of adversaries, and privacy protection. Our results demonstrate that, in a network with N𝑁N mobile users, BREA can theoretically guarantee: i) robustness of the trained model against up to A𝐴A Byzantine adversaries, ii) tolerance against up to D𝐷D user dropouts, iii) privacy of each local update, against the server and up to T𝑇T colluding users, as long as N≥2​A+1+max⁡{m+2,D+2​T}𝑁2𝐴1𝑚2𝐷2𝑇N\geq 2A+1+\max\{m+2,D+2T\}, where m𝑚m is the number of selected models for aggregation.

We then numerically evaluate the performance of BREA and compare it to the conventional federated learning protocol, the federated averaging scheme of [2]. To do so, we implement BREA in a distributed network of N=40𝑁40N=40 users with up to A=12𝐴12A=12 Byzantine users who can send arbitrary vectors to the server or to the honest users. We demonstrate that BREA guarantees convergence against Byzantine users and its convergence rate is comparable to the convergence rate of federated averaging. BREA also has comparable test accuracy to the federated averaging scheme while BREA entails quantization loss to preserve the privacy of individual users.

Finally, while BREA provides the first distributed training framework that is both Byzantine-resilient and privacy-preserving, there are several directions for further improvements. The first is that our theoretical analysis for convergence needs the assumption of an independent and identically distributed (i.i.d.) data distribution over the users. Second, we rely on distance-based outlier removal mechanisms, which make it difficult to distinguish whether a large distance between local updates is due to a non-i.i.d. data distribution or a Byzantine attack. Providing theoretical performance guarantees for non-i.i.d. data in the Byzantine-robust training setups is an important and interesting direction for future research. However, one should also note that even without the privacy requirements, this is still an open problem and an active area of research in the literature  [20, 21]. Other open questions include whether it is possible to break the quadratic communication and computation complexity of Byzantine-resilient secure aggregation in the current work, and investigating the fundamental performance limits of Byzantine-resilient distributed learning with multiple local updates.

II Related Work

In the non-Byzantine federated learning setting, secure aggregation is performed through a procedure known as additive masking [3], [22]. In this setup, users first agree on pairwise secret keys using a Diffie-Hellman type key exchange protocol [23], and send a masked version of their local update to the server, where the masking is done using pairwise and private secret keys. When the masked models are aggregated at the server, additive masks cancel out, allowing the server to learn the aggregate of the local updates. This process works well if no users drop during the execution of the protocol. In wireless environments, however, users may drop from the protocol anytime due to the variations in channel conditions. Such user dropouts are handled by letting each user secret share their private and pairwise keys through Shamir’s secret sharing [19]. The server can remove the additive masks by collecting the secret shares from the surviving users. This approach leads to a quadratic communication overhead in the number of users. More recent approaches have focused on reducing the communication overhead, by training in a smaller parameter space [24], autotuning the parameters[25], or by utilizing coding techniques [7].

Another line of work has focused on differentially-private federated learning approaches [26, 27], to protect the privacy of personally-identifiable information against inference attacks. Although our focus is not on differential-privacy, our approach may in principle be combined with differential privacy techniques [28], which is an interesting future direction. Another important direction in federated learning is the study of fairness and how to avoid biasing the model towards specific users [29, 30]. The convergence properties of federated learning models are investigated in [31].

Distributed training protocols have been extensively studied in the Byzantine setting using clear (unmasked) model updates [10, 11, 12, 13, 14, 20, 21]. The main defense mechanism to protect the trained model against Byzantine users is by comparing the model updates received from different users, and removing the outliers. Doing so ensures that the selected model updates are close to each other, as long as the network has a sufficiently large number of honest users. A related line of work is model poisoning attacks, which are studied in [32, 33].

In concurrent work, a Byzantine-robust secure gradient descent algorithm has been proposed for a two-server model in [34], however, unlike federated learning (which is based on a single-server architecture) [2, 3], this work requires two honest (non-colluding) servers who both interact with the mobile users and communicate with each other to carry out a secure two-party protocol, but do not share any sensitive information with each other in an attempt to breach user privacy. In contrast, our goal is to develop a single-server Byzantine-resilient secure training framework, to facilitate robust and privacy-preserving training architectures for federated learning. Compared to the two-server models, single server models carry the additional challenge where all information has to be collected at a single server, while still being able to keep the individual models of the users private.

The remainder of the paper is organized as follows. In Section III, we provide background on federated learning. Section IV presents our system model along with the key parameters used to evaluate the system performance. Section V introduces our framework and the details of the specific components. Section VI presents our theoretical results, whereas our numerical evaluations are provided in Section VII, to demonstrate the convergence and Byzantine-resilience. The paper is concluded in Section VIII. The following notation is used throughout the paper. We represent a scalar variable with x𝑥x, whereas 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} represents a vector. A set is denoted by 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}, whereas [N]delimited-[]𝑁[N] refers to the set {1,…,N}1…𝑁\{1,\ldots,N\}.

III Background

Federated learning is a distributed training framework for machine learning in mobile networks while preserving the privacy of users. Training is coordinated by a central server who maintains a global model 𝐰∈ℝd𝐰superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbf{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} with dimension d𝑑d. The goal is to train the global model using the data held at mobile devices, by minimizing a global objective function C​(𝐰)𝐶𝐰C(\mathbf{w}) as,

min𝐰⁡C​(𝐰).subscript𝐰𝐶𝐰\min_{\mathbf{w}}C(\mathbf{w}). (1)

The global model is updated locally by mobile users on sensitive private datasets, by letting

where N𝑁N is the total number of mobile users, Ci​(𝐰)subscript𝐶𝑖𝐰C_{i}(\mathbf{w}) denotes the local objective function of user i𝑖i, Bisubscript𝐵𝑖B_{i} is the number of data points in user i𝑖i’s private dataset 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i}, and B:=∑i=1NBiassign𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝐵𝑖B:=\sum_{i=1}^{N}B_{i}. Training is performed through an iterative process where mobile users interact through the central server to update the global model. At each iteration, the server shares the current state of the global model, denoted by 𝐰(t)superscript𝐰𝑡\mathbf{w}^{(t)}, with the mobile users. Each user i𝑖i creates a local update,

The local updates are aggregated at the server in a privacy-preserving protocol, such that the server only learns the aggregate of a large fraction of the local updates, ideally the sum of all user models ∑i∈[N]𝐰i(t)subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑁superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑖𝑡\sum_{i\in[N]}\mathbf{w}_{i}^{(t)}, but no further information is revealed about the individual models beyond their aggregated value. Using the aggregate of the local updates, the server updates the global model for the next iteration,

Conventional secure aggregation protocols require each user to mask its local update using random keys before aggregation [3, 7, 35]. This is typically done by creating pairwise keys between the users through a key exchange protocol [23]. Using the pairwise keys, each pair of users i,j∈[N]𝑖𝑗delimited-[]𝑁i,j\in[N] agree on a pairwise random seed ai​j(t)superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑖𝑗𝑡a_{ij}^{(t)}. to the server, where PRG is a pseudo random generator. For computing the aggregate of the user models, the server collects either the secret shares of the pairwise seeds belonging to a dropped user, or the shares of the private seed belonging to a surviving user (but not both). IV Problem Formulation

In this section, we describe the Byzantine-resilient secure aggregation problem, by extending the conventional secure aggregation scenario from Section III to the case when some users, known as Byzantine adversaries, can manipulate the trained model by modifying their local datasets or by sharing false information during the protocol.

We consider a distributed network with N𝑁N mobile users and a single server. User i∈[N]𝑖delimited-[]𝑁i\in[N] holds a local update111For notational clarity, throughout Sections IV and V, we omit the iteration number (t)𝑡(t) from 𝐰i(t)superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑖𝑡\mathbf{w}_{i}^{(t)}. 𝐰isubscript𝐰𝑖\mathbf{w}_{i} of dimension d𝑑d. The goal is to aggregate the local updates at the server, while protecting the privacy of individual users. However, unlike the non-Byzantine setting of Section III, the aggregation operation in the Byzantine setting should be robust against potentially malicious users. To this end, we represent the aggregation operation by a function,

f​(𝐰1,…,𝐰N)=∑i∈𝒮𝐰i𝑓subscript𝐰1…subscript𝐰𝑁subscript𝑖𝒮subscript𝐰𝑖f(\mathbf{w}_{1},\ldots,\mathbf{w}_{N})=\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}}\mathbf{w}_{i} (8)

where 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} is a set of users selected by the server for aggregation. The role of 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} is to remove the effect of potentially Byzantine adversaries on the trained model, by removing the outliers. Similar to prior works on federated learning, our focus is on computationally-bounded parties, whose strategies can be described by a probabilistic polynomial time algorithm [3].

We evaluate the performance of a Byzantine-resilient secure aggregation protocol according to the following key parameters:

  • •

    Robustness against Byzantine users: We assume that up to A𝐴A users are Byzantine (malicious), who manipulate the protocol by modifying their local datasets or by sharing false information during protocol execution. The protocol should be robust against such Byzantine adversaries.

  • •

    Privacy of local updates: The aggregation protocol should protect the privacy of any individual user from the server and any collusions between up to T𝑇T users. Specifically, the local update of any user should not be revealed to the server or the remaining users, even if up to T𝑇T users cooperate with each other by sharing information.222Collusions that may occur between the server and the users are beyond the scope of our paper.

  • •

    Tolerance to user dropouts: Due to potentially poor wireless channel conditions, we assume that up to D𝐷D users may get dropped or delayed at any time during protocol execution. The protocol should be able to tolerate such dropouts, i.e., the privacy and convergence guarantees should hold even if up to D𝐷D users drop or get delayed.

In this paper, we present a single-server Byzantine-resilient secure aggregation framework (BREA) for the computation of (8). BREA consists of the following key components:

  1. 1.

    Stochastic quantization: Users initially quantize their local updates from the real domain to the domain of integers, and then embed them in a field 𝔽psubscript𝔽𝑝\mathbb{F}_{p} of integers modulo a prime p𝑝{p}. To do so, our framework utilizes stochastic quantization, which is instrumental in our theoretical convergence guarantees.

  2. 2.

    Verifiable secret sharing of the user models: Users then secret share their quantized models using a verifiable secret sharing protocol. This ensures that the secret shares created by the mobile users are valid, i.e., Byzantine users cannot cheat by sending invalid secret shares.

  3. 3.

    Secure distance computation: In this phase, users compute the pairwise distances between the secret shares of the local updates, and send the results to the server. Since this computation is performed using the secret shares of the models instead of their true values, users do not learn any information about the actual model parameters.

  4. 4.

    User selection at the server: Upon receiving the computation results from the users, the server recovers the pairwise distances between the local updates and selects the set of users whose models will be included in the aggregation, by removing the outliers. This ensures that the aggregated model is robust against potential manipulations from Byzantine users. The server then announces the list of the selected users.

  5. 5.

    Secure model aggregation: In the final phase, each user locally aggregates the secret shares of the models selected by the server, and sends the computation result to the server. Using the computation results, the server recovers the aggregate of the models of the selected users, and updates the model.

In the following, we describe the details of each phase.

V The BREA Framework

In this section, we present the details of the BREA framework for Byzantine-resilient secure federated learning.

V-A Stochastic Quantization

In BREA, the operations for verifiable secret sharing and secure distance computations are carried out over a finite field 𝔽psubscript𝔽𝑝\mathbb{F}_{p} for some large prime p𝑝{p}. To this end, user i∈[N]𝑖delimited-[]𝑁i\in[N] initially quantizes its local update 𝐰isubscript𝐰𝑖\mathbf{w}_{i} from the domain of real numbers to the finite field. We assume that the field size p𝑝{p} is large enough to avoid any wrap-around during secure distance computation and secure model aggregation, which will be described in Sections V-C and V-E, respectively.

Quantization requires a challenging task as it should be performed in a way to ensure the convergence of the model. Moreover, the quantization function should allow the representation of negative integers in the finite field, and facilitate computations to be performed in the quantized domain. Therefore, we cannot utilize well-known gradient quantization techniques such as in [36], which represents the sign of a negative number separately from its magnitude. BREA addresses this challenge with a simple stochastic quantization strategy as follows. For any integer q≥1𝑞1q\geq 1, we define a stochastic rounding function:

Qq​(x)={⌊q​x⌋qwith prob. ​1−(q​x−⌊q​x⌋)⌊q​x⌋+1qwith prob. ​q​x−⌊q​x⌋subscript𝑄𝑞𝑥cases𝑞𝑥𝑞with prob. 1𝑞𝑥𝑞𝑥𝑞𝑥1𝑞with prob. 𝑞𝑥𝑞𝑥Q_{q}(x)=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}\frac{\lfloor qx\rfloor}{q}&\text{with prob. }1-(qx-\lfloor qx\rfloor)\\ \frac{\lfloor qx\rfloor+1}{q}&\text{with prob. }qx-\lfloor qx\rfloor\end{array}\right. (9)

where ⌊x⌋𝑥\lfloor x\rfloor is the largest integer less than or equal to x𝑥x, and note that this function is unbiased, i.e., 𝔼Q​[Qq​(x)]=xsubscript𝔼𝑄delimited-[]subscript𝑄𝑞𝑥𝑥\mathbb{E}_{Q}[Q_{q}(x)]=x. Parameter q𝑞q is a tuning parameter that corresponds to the number of quantization levels. Variance of Qq​(x)subscript𝑄𝑞𝑥Q_{q}(x) decreases as the value of q𝑞q increases, which will be detailed in Lemma 1 in Section VI. We then define the quantized model,

𝐰¯i:=ϕ​(q⋅Qq​(𝐰i))assignsubscript¯𝐰𝑖italic-ϕ⋅𝑞subscript𝑄𝑞subscript𝐰𝑖\overline{\mathbf{w}}_{i}:=\phi(q\cdot Q_{q}({\mathbf{w}}_{i})) (10)

where the function Qqsubscript𝑄𝑞Q_{q} from (9) is carried out element-wise, and a mapping function ϕ:ℝ→𝔽p:italic-ϕ→ℝsubscript𝔽𝑝\phi:\mathbb{R}\rightarrow\mathbb{F}_{p} is defined to represent a negative integer in the finite field by using two’s complement representation,

ϕ​(x)={xif ​x≥0p+xif ​x<0.italic-ϕ𝑥cases𝑥if 𝑥0𝑝𝑥if 𝑥0\phi(x)=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}x&\text{if }x\geq 0\\ p+x&\text{if }x<0.\end{array}\right. (11)

V-B Verifiable Secret Sharing of the User Models

BREA protects the privacy of individual user models through verifiable secret sharing. This is to ensure that the individual user models are kept private while preventing the Byzantine users from breaking the integrity of the protocol by sending invalid secret shares to the other users.

To do so, user i∈[N]𝑖delimited-[]𝑁i\in[N] secret shares its quantized model 𝐰¯isubscript¯𝐰𝑖\overline{\mathbf{w}}_{i} with the other users through a non-interactive verifiable secret sharing protocol [18]. Our framework leverages Feldman’s verifiable secret sharing protocol from [18], which combines Shamir’s secret sharing [19] with homomorphic encryption. In this setup, each party creates the secret shares, then broadcasts commitments to the coefficients of the polynomial they use for Shamir’s secret sharing, so that other parties can verify that the secret shares are constructed correctly. To verify the secret shares from the given commitments, the protocol leverages the homomorphic property of exponentiation, i.e., e​x​p​(a+b)=e​x​p​(a)​e​x​p​(b)𝑒𝑥𝑝𝑎𝑏𝑒𝑥𝑝𝑎𝑒𝑥𝑝𝑏exp(a+b)=exp(a)exp(b), whereas the privacy protection is based on the assumption that computation of the discrete logarithm in the finite field is intractable.

The individual steps carried out for verifiable secret sharing in our framework are as follows. Initially, the server and users agree on N𝑁N distinct elements {θi}i∈[N]subscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖𝑖delimited-[]𝑁\{\theta_{i}\}_{i\in[N]} from 𝔽psubscript𝔽𝑝\mathbb{F}_{p}. This can be done offline by using a conventional majority-based consensus protocol [37, 38]. User i∈[N]𝑖delimited-[]𝑁i\in[N] then generates secret shares of the quantized model 𝐰¯isubscript¯𝐰𝑖\overline{\mathbf{w}}_{i} by forming a random polynomial fi:𝔽p→𝔽pd:subscript𝑓𝑖→subscript𝔽𝑝superscriptsubscript𝔽𝑝𝑑f_{i}\!:\!\mathbb{F}_{p}\!\rightarrow\!\mathbb{F}_{p}^{d} of degree T𝑇{T},

fi​(θ)=𝐰¯i+∑j=1T𝐫i​j​θjsubscript𝑓𝑖𝜃subscript¯𝐰𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑇subscript𝐫𝑖𝑗superscript𝜃𝑗f_{i}(\theta)=\overline{\mathbf{w}}_{i}+\sum_{j=1}^{T}\mathbf{r}_{ij}\theta^{j} (12)

in which the vectors 𝐫i​jsubscript𝐫𝑖𝑗\mathbf{r}_{ij} are generated uniformly at random from 𝔽pdsubscriptsuperscript𝔽𝑑𝑝\mathbb{F}^{d}_{p} by user i𝑖i. User i𝑖i then sends a secret share of 𝐰¯isubscript¯𝐰𝑖\overline{\mathbf{w}}_{i} to user j𝑗j, denoted by,

𝐬i​j=fi​(θj).subscript𝐬𝑖𝑗subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝜃𝑗\mathbf{s}_{ij}=f_{i}(\theta_{j}). (13)

To make these shares verifiable, user i𝑖i also broadcasts commitments to the coefficients of fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i}, given by

𝐜i​j={ψ𝐰¯ifor ​j=0ψ𝐫i​jfor ​j=1,…,T.subscript𝐜𝑖𝑗casessuperscript𝜓subscript¯𝐰𝑖for 𝑗0superscript𝜓subscript𝐫𝑖𝑗for 𝑗1…𝑇\mathbf{c}_{ij}=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}\psi^{\overline{\mathbf{w}}_{i}}&\text{for }j=0\\ \psi^{\mathbf{r}_{ij}}&\text{for }j=1,\ldots,{T}.\end{array}\right. (14)

where ψ𝜓\psi denotes a generator of 𝔽psubscript𝔽𝑝\mathbb{F}_{p}, and all arithmetic is taken modulo λ𝜆\lambda for some large prime λ𝜆\lambda such that p𝑝p divides λ−1𝜆1\lambda-1.

Upon receiving the commitments in (14), each user j∈[N]𝑗delimited-[]𝑁j\in[N] can verify the secret share 𝐬i​j=fi​(θj)subscript𝐬𝑖𝑗subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝜃𝑗\mathbf{s}_{ij}=f_{i}(\theta_{j}) by checking

ψ𝐬i​j=∏k=0T𝐜i​kθjksuperscript𝜓subscript𝐬𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑘0𝑇superscriptsubscript𝐜𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑗𝑘\psi^{\mathbf{s}_{ij}}=\prod_{k=0}^{T}\mathbf{c}_{ik}^{\theta_{j}^{k}} (15)

where all arithmetic is taken modulo λ𝜆\lambda. This commitment scheme ensures that the secret shares are created correctly from the polynomial in (12), hence they are valid. On the other hand, as we assume the intractability of computing the discrete logarithm [18], the server or the users cannot compute the discrete logarithm logψ⁡(𝐜i​t)subscript𝜓subscript𝐜𝑖𝑡\log_{\psi}(\mathbf{c}_{it}) and reveal the quantized model 𝐰¯isubscript¯𝐰𝑖\overline{\mathbf{w}}_{i} from 𝐜i​0subscript𝐜𝑖0\mathbf{c}_{i0} in (14).

V-C Secure Distance Computation

Verifiable secret sharing of the model parameters, as described in Section V-B, ensures that the users follow the protocol correctly by creating valid secret shares. However, malicious users can still try to manipulate the trained model by modifying their local updates instead. In this case, the secret shares will be created correctly but according to a false model. In order to ensure that the trained model is robust against such adversarial manipulations, BREA leverages a distance-based outlier detection mechanism, such as in [39, 10]. The main principle behind these mechanisms is to compute the pairwise distances between the local updates and select a set of models that are sufficiently close to each other. On the other hand, the outlier detection mechanism in BREA has to protect the privacy of local updates, and performing the distance computations on the true values of the model parameters would breach the privacy of individual users.

We address this by a privacy-preserving distance computation approach, in which the pairwise distances are computed locally by each user, using the secret shares of the model parameters received from the other users. In particular, upon receiving the secret shares of the model parameters as described in Section V-B, user i𝑖i computes the pairwise distances,

dj​k(i):=∥𝐬j​i−𝐬k​i∥2assignsubscriptsuperscript𝑑𝑖𝑗𝑘superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝐬𝑗𝑖subscript𝐬𝑘𝑖2d^{(i)}_{jk}:=\lVert\mathbf{s}_{ji}-\mathbf{s}_{ki}\rVert^{2} (16)

between each pair of users j,k∈[N]𝑗𝑘delimited-[]𝑁j,k\in[N], and sends the result to the server. Since the computations in (16) are performed over the secret shares, user i𝑖i learns no information about the true values of the model parameters 𝐰¯jsubscript¯𝐰𝑗\overline{\mathbf{w}}_{j} and 𝐰¯ksubscript¯𝐰𝑘\overline{\mathbf{w}}_{k} of users j𝑗j and k𝑘k, respectively. Finally, we note that the computation results from (16) are scalar values.

V-D User Selection at the Server

Upon receiving the computation results in (16) from a sufficient number of users, the server reconstructs the true values of the pairwise distances. During this phase, Byzantine users may send incorrect computation results to the server, hence the reconstruction process should be able to correct the potential errors that may occur in the computation results due to malicious users. Our decoding procedure is based on the decoding of Reed-Solomon codes.

The intuition of the decoding process is that the computations from (16) correspond to evaluation points of a univariate polynomial hj​k:𝔽p→𝔽p:subscriptℎ𝑗𝑘→subscript𝔽𝑝subscript𝔽𝑝h_{jk}\!:\!\mathbb{F}_{p}\!\rightarrow\!\mathbb{F}_{p} of degree at most 2​T2𝑇2T, where

hj​k​(θ):=∥fj​(θ)−fk​(θ)∥2assignsubscriptℎ𝑗𝑘𝜃superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝑓𝑗𝜃subscript𝑓𝑘𝜃2h_{jk}(\theta):=\lVert f_{j}(\theta)-f_{k}(\theta)\rVert^{2} (17)

for θ∈{θi}i∈[N]𝜃subscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖𝑖delimited-[]𝑁\theta\in\{\theta_{i}\}_{i\in[N]} and j,k∈[N]𝑗𝑘delimited-[]𝑁j,k\in[N]. Accordingly, hj​ksubscriptℎ𝑗𝑘h_{jk} can be viewed as the encoding polynomial of a Reed-Solomon code with degree at most 2​T2𝑇2{T}, such that the missing computations due to the dropped users correspond to the erasures in the code, and manipulated computations from Byzantine users refer to the errors in the code. Therefore, the decoding process of the server corresponds to decoding an [N,2​T+1,N−2​T]psubscript𝑁2𝑇1𝑁2𝑇𝑝[N,2{T}+1,N-2{T}]_{p} Reed-Solomon code with at most D𝐷D erasures and at most A𝐴A errors. By utilizing well-known Reed-Solomon decoding algorithms [40], the server can recover the polynomial hj​ksubscriptℎ𝑗𝑘h_{jk} and obtain the true value of the pairwise distances by using the relation hj​k​(0)=∥fj​(0)−fk​(0)∥2=∥𝐰¯j−𝐰¯k∥2subscriptℎ𝑗𝑘0superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝑓𝑗0subscript𝑓𝑘02superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript¯𝐰𝑗subscript¯𝐰𝑘2h_{jk}(0)=\lVert f_{j}(0)-f_{k}(0)\rVert^{2}=\lVert\overline{\mathbf{w}}_{j}-\overline{\mathbf{w}}_{k}\rVert^{2}. At the end, the server learns the pairwise distances

d¯j​k:=∥𝐰¯j−𝐰¯k∥2assignsubscript¯𝑑𝑗𝑘superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript¯𝐰𝑗subscript¯𝐰𝑘2\overline{d}_{jk}:=\lVert\overline{\mathbf{w}}_{j}-\overline{\mathbf{w}}_{k}\rVert^{2} (18)

between the models of users j,k∈[N]𝑗𝑘delimited-[]𝑁j,k\in[N]. Then the server converts (18) from the finite field to the real domain as follows,

dj​k=ϕ−1​(d¯j​k)q2subscript𝑑𝑗𝑘superscriptitalic-ϕ1subscript¯𝑑𝑗𝑘superscript𝑞2{d}_{jk}=\frac{{\phi}^{-1}(\overline{d}_{jk})}{q^{2}} (19)

for j,k∈[N]𝑗𝑘delimited-[]𝑁j,k\in[N], where q𝑞q is the integer parameter in (9) and the demapping function ϕ−1:𝔽p→ℝ:superscriptitalic-ϕ1→subscript𝔽𝑝ℝ\phi^{-1}:\mathbb{F}_{p}\rightarrow\mathbb{R} is defined as

ϕ−1​(x¯)={x¯if ​0≤x¯<p−12x¯−pif ​p−12≤x¯<p.superscriptitalic-ϕ1¯𝑥cases¯𝑥if 0¯𝑥𝑝12¯𝑥𝑝if 𝑝12¯𝑥𝑝{\phi}^{-1}(\overline{x})=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}\overline{x}&\text{if \quad}0\leq\overline{x}<\frac{p-1}{2}\\ \overline{x}-p&\text{if \quad}\frac{p-1}{2}\leq\overline{x}<p\end{array}.\right. (20)

We assume the field size p𝑝p is large enough to ensure the correct recovery of the pairwise distances,

dj​ksubscript𝑑𝑗𝑘\displaystyle{d}_{jk} =ϕ−1​(∥ϕ​(q⋅Qq​(𝐰j))−ϕ​(q⋅Qq​(𝐰k))∥2)q2absentsuperscriptitalic-ϕ1superscriptdelimited-∥∥italic-ϕ⋅𝑞subscript𝑄𝑞subscript𝐰𝑗italic-ϕ⋅𝑞subscript𝑄𝑞subscript𝐰𝑘2superscript𝑞2\displaystyle=\frac{\phi^{-1}\big{(}\lVert\phi(q\cdot Q_{q}(\mathbf{w}_{j}))-\phi(q\cdot Q_{q}(\mathbf{w}_{k}))\rVert^{2}\big{)}}{q^{2}}

where Qqsubscript𝑄𝑞Q_{q} is the stochastic rounding function defined in (9) and (21) holds if

q2​∥Qq​(𝐰j)−Qq​(𝐰k)∥2<(p−1)/2.superscript𝑞2superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝑄𝑞subscript𝐰𝑗subscript𝑄𝑞subscript𝐰𝑘2𝑝12q^{2}\lVert Q_{q}(\mathbf{w}_{j})-Q_{q}(\mathbf{w}_{k})\rVert^{2}<(p-1)/2. (23)

By utilizing the pairwise distances in (22), the server carries out a distance-based outlier removal algorithm to select the set of users to include in the final model aggregation. The outlier removal procedure of BREA follows the multi-Krum algorithm from [39, 10]. The main difference is that our framework considers the multi-Krum algorithm in a quantized stochastic gradient setting, as BREA utilizes quantized gradients instead of the true gradients, in order to enable privacy-preserving computations on the secret shares. We present the theoretical convergence guarantees of this quantized multi-Krum algorithm in Section VI, and numerically demonstrate its convergence behaviour in our experiments in Section VII.

In this setup, the server selects m𝑚m users through the following iterative process. At each iteration k∈[m]𝑘delimited-[]𝑚k\in[m], the server selects one user, denoted by i(k)superscript𝑖𝑘i^{(k)}, by finding

i(k)=arg⁡minj∈[N]∖𝒮(k−1)⁡s(k)​(j)superscript𝑖𝑘subscript𝑗delimited-[]𝑁superscript𝒮𝑘1superscript𝑠𝑘𝑗i^{(k)}=\arg\min_{j\in[N]\setminus\mathcal{S}^{(k-1)}}s^{(k)}(j) (24)

where 𝒮(k)superscript𝒮𝑘\mathcal{S}^{(k)} denotes the index set of the users selected in up to k𝑘k iterations and s(k)​(j)superscript𝑠𝑘𝑗s^{(k)}(j) is a score function assigned to user j𝑗j at iteration k𝑘k. The score function of user j𝑗j is defined as

s(k)​(j)=∑u∈ℐj(k−1)dj​usuperscript𝑠𝑘𝑗subscript𝑢subscriptsuperscriptℐ𝑘1𝑗subscript𝑑𝑗𝑢s^{(k)}(j)=\sum_{u\in\mathcal{I}^{(k-1)}_{j}}d_{ju} (25)

where ℐj(k−1)⊆[N]∖𝒮(k−1)subscriptsuperscriptℐ𝑘1𝑗delimited-[]𝑁superscript𝒮𝑘1\mathcal{I}^{(k-1)}_{j}\subseteq[N]\setminus\mathcal{S}^{(k-1)} denotes the set of (N−k+1)−A−2𝑁𝑘1𝐴2(N-k+1)-A-2 users whose models are closest to the model of user j𝑗j. After selecting i(k)superscript𝑖𝑘i^{(k)}, the server updates the selected index set as 𝒮(k)={𝒮(k−1),i(k)}superscript𝒮𝑘superscript𝒮𝑘1superscript𝑖𝑘\mathcal{S}^{(k)}=\{\mathcal{S}^{(k-1)},i^{(k)}\} where 𝒮(0)=∅superscript𝒮0\mathcal{S}^{(0)}=\emptyset. After m𝑚m iterations, the server obtains the index set 𝒮=𝒮(m)𝒮superscript𝒮𝑚\mathcal{S}=\mathcal{S}^{(m)}.

V-E Secure Model Aggregation

The final phase of BREA is to securely aggregate the local updates of the selected users, without revealing the individual models to the server. To do so, the server initially announces the list of selected users via broadcasting. We denote the set of selected users by 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}. Then, each user locally aggregates the secret shares belonging to the selected users,

𝐬i=∑j∈𝒮𝐬j​isubscript𝐬𝑖subscript𝑗𝒮subscript𝐬𝑗𝑖\mathbf{s}_{i}=\sum_{j\in\mathcal{S}}\mathbf{s}_{ji} (26)

and sends the result to the server. Upon receiving the computation results from a sufficient number of users, the server can decode the aggregate of the models ∑j∈𝒮𝐰¯jsubscript𝑗𝒮subscript¯𝐰𝑗\sum_{j\in\mathcal{S}}\overline{\mathbf{w}}_{j} through the decoding of Reed-Solomon codes.

The intuition of the decoding process is similar to the decoding of the pairwise distances described in Section V-D. Specifically, the computations from (26) can be viewed as evaluation points of a univariate polynomial h::𝔽p→𝔽pdh:\!:\!\mathbb{F}_{p}\!\rightarrow\!\mathbb{F}_{p}^{d} of degree at most T𝑇{T},

h​(θ):=∑j∈𝒮fj​(θ).assignℎ𝜃subscript𝑗𝒮subscript𝑓𝑗𝜃h(\theta):=\sum_{j\in\mathcal{S}}f_{j}(\theta). (27)

One can then observe that hℎh is the encoding polynomial of a Reed-Solomon code with degree at most T𝑇T, the missing computations due to the dropped users correspond to the erasures in the code, and manipulated computations from Byzantine users correspond to the errors in the code. Therefore, the decoding process of the server corresponds to decoding an [N,T+1,N−T]psubscript𝑁𝑇1𝑁𝑇𝑝[N,{T}+1,N-{T}]_{p} Reed-Solomon code with at most D𝐷D erasures and at most A𝐴A errors. Hence, by using a Reed-Solomon decoding algorithm, the server can recover the polynomial hℎh and obtain the true value of the aggregate of the selected user models by using the relation h​(0)=∑j∈𝒮fj​(0)=∑j∈𝒮𝐰¯jℎ0subscript𝑗𝒮subscript𝑓𝑗0subscript𝑗𝒮subscript¯𝐰𝑗h(0)=\sum_{j\in\mathcal{S}}f_{j}(0)=\sum_{j\in\mathcal{S}}\overline{\mathbf{w}}_{j}. We note that the total number of users selected by the server for aggregation, i.e., |𝒮|=m𝒮𝑚|\mathcal{S}|=m, should be sufficiently large, which can be agreed offline between the users and the server. Then, if the set announced by the server is too small (e.g., consisting of a single user), the honest users may opt to not send the computation results.

Upon learning the aggregate of the user models, the server updates the global model for the next iteration as follows,

𝐰(t+1)=𝐰(t)−γ(t)q​ϕ−1​(∑j∈𝒮𝐰¯j(t))superscript𝐰𝑡1superscript𝐰𝑡superscript𝛾𝑡𝑞superscriptitalic-ϕ1subscript𝑗𝒮superscriptsubscript¯𝐰𝑗𝑡\mathbf{w}^{(t+1)}=\mathbf{w}^{(t)}-\frac{\gamma^{(t)}}{q}\phi^{-1}\Big{(}\sum_{j\in\mathcal{S}}\overline{\mathbf{w}}_{j}^{(t)}\Big{)} (28)

where ϕ−1superscriptitalic-ϕ1\phi^{-1} is the demapping function defined in (20) and q𝑞q is the integer parameter in (9). We assume that the field size p𝑝p is large enough to avoid wrap-around in ∑j∈𝒮𝐰¯j(t)subscript𝑗𝒮superscriptsubscript¯𝐰𝑗𝑡\sum_{j\in\mathcal{S}}\overline{\mathbf{w}}_{j}^{(t)} such that

∑j∈𝒮𝐰¯j(t)subscript𝑗𝒮superscriptsubscript¯𝐰𝑗𝑡\displaystyle\sum_{j\in\mathcal{S}}\overline{\mathbf{w}}_{j}^{(t)} =∑j∈𝒮ϕ​(q⋅Qq​(𝐰j(t)))absentsubscript𝑗𝒮italic-ϕ⋅𝑞subscript𝑄𝑞subscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑡𝑗\displaystyle=\sum_{j\in\mathcal{S}}\phi(q\cdot Q_{q}(\mathbf{w}^{(t)}_{j})) (29)
=ϕ​(q​∑j∈𝒮𝐰j(t))absentitalic-ϕ𝑞subscript𝑗𝒮subscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑡𝑗\displaystyle=\phi\big{(}q\sum_{j\in\mathcal{S}}\mathbf{w}^{(t)}_{j}\big{)} (30)

where (29) follows from (10). Finally, it follows from (30) that the update equation in (28) is equivalent to

𝐰(t+1)=𝐰(t)−γ(t)​∑j∈𝒮Qq​(𝐰j(t))superscript𝐰𝑡1superscript𝐰𝑡superscript𝛾𝑡subscript𝑗𝒮subscript𝑄𝑞subscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑡𝑗\mathbf{w}^{(t+1)}=\mathbf{w}^{(t)}-\gamma^{(t)}\sum_{j\in\mathcal{S}}Q_{q}(\mathbf{w}^{(t)}_{j}) (31)

where Qqsubscript𝑄𝑞Q_{q} is the stochastic rounding function defined in (9).

Having all above steps, the overall BREA framework can now be presented in Algorithm 1.

VI Theoretical Analysis

In this section, we analyze the fundamental performance limits of BREA. The global model update equation of BREA can be expressed as follows,

𝐰(t+1)=𝐰(t)−γ(t)​f​(Qq​(𝐰1(t)),…,Qq​(𝐰N(t)))superscript𝐰𝑡1superscript𝐰𝑡superscript𝛾𝑡𝑓subscript𝑄𝑞subscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑡1…subscript𝑄𝑞subscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑡𝑁\mathbf{w}^{(t+1)}=\mathbf{w}^{(t)}-\gamma^{(t)}f\big{(}Q_{q}(\mathbf{w}^{(t)}_{1}),\ldots,Q_{q}(\mathbf{w}^{(t)}_{N})\big{)} (32)

where f𝑓f is the aggregation operation from (8) and represents the user selection and model aggregation procedures from Sections V-D and V-E, respectively, while Qqsubscript𝑄𝑞Q_{q} is the stochastic rounding function defined in (9).

As described in Section III, the local update 𝐰i(t)subscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑡𝑖\mathbf{w}^{(t)}_{i} created by an honest user is an unbiased estimator of the true gradient, i.e., 𝐰i(t)=g​(𝐰(t),ξi(t))subscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑡𝑖𝑔superscript𝐰𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝜉𝑡𝑖\mathbf{w}^{(t)}_{i}=g(\mathbf{w}^{(t)},\xi^{(t)}_{i}) with 𝔼ξ​[g​(𝐰(t),ξi(t))]=∇C​(𝐰(t))subscript𝔼𝜉delimited-[]𝑔superscript𝐰𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝜉𝑡𝑖∇𝐶superscript𝐰𝑡\mathbb{E}_{\xi}[g(\mathbf{w}^{(t)},\xi^{(t)}_{i})]=\nabla C(\mathbf{w}^{(t)}) where ξi(t)∼ξsimilar-tosuperscriptsubscript𝜉𝑖𝑡𝜉\xi_{i}^{(t)}\sim\xi and ξ𝜉\xi is a uniform random variable representing the random sample (or a mini-batch of samples) drawn from the dataset. We define the local standard deviation σ𝜎\sigma of the gradient estimator g𝑔g by

d​σ2​(𝐰):=𝔼ξ​∥g​(𝐰,ξ)−∇C​(𝐰)∥2assign𝑑superscript𝜎2𝐰subscript𝔼𝜉superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑔𝐰𝜉∇𝐶𝐰2d\sigma^{2}(\mathbf{w}):=\mathbb{E}_{\xi}\lVert g(\mathbf{w},\xi)-\nabla C(\mathbf{w})\rVert^{2} (33)

for all 𝐰∈ℝd𝐰superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbf{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}. The model created by a Byzantine user can refer to any random vector 𝐛i(t)∈ℝdsuperscriptsubscript𝐛𝑖𝑡superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbf{b}_{i}^{(t)}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, which we represent as 𝐰i(t)=𝐛i(t)subscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑡𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐛𝑖𝑡\mathbf{w}^{(t)}_{i}=\mathbf{b}_{i}^{(t)}. Accordingly, the quantized model Q​(𝐰i(t))𝑄subscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑡𝑖Q(\mathbf{w}^{(t)}_{i}) of Byzantine user could refer to any vector in ℤdsuperscriptℤ𝑑\mathbb{Z}^{d}.

Our first lemma states the unbiasedness and bounded variance of the quantized gradient estimator Qq​(g​(𝐰,ξ))subscript𝑄𝑞𝑔𝐰𝜉Q_{q}(g(\mathbf{w},\xi)) for any vector 𝐰∈ℝd𝐰superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbf{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.

Lemma 1.

For the quantized gradient estimator Qq​(g​(𝐰,ξ))subscript𝑄𝑞𝑔𝐰𝜉Q_{q}(g(\mathbf{w},\xi)) with a given vector 𝐰∈ℝd𝐰superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbf{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} where ξ𝜉\xi is a uniform random variable representing the sample drawn, g𝑔g is a gradient estimator such that 𝔼ξ​[g​(𝐰,ξ)]=∇C​(𝐰)subscript𝔼𝜉delimited-[]𝑔𝐰𝜉∇𝐶𝐰\mathbb{E}_{\xi}[g(\mathbf{w},\xi)]=\nabla C(\mathbf{w}) and 𝔼ξ​∥g​(𝐰,ξ)−∇C​(𝐰)∥2=d​σ2​(𝐰)subscript𝔼𝜉superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑔𝐰𝜉∇𝐶𝐰2𝑑superscript𝜎2𝐰\mathbb{E}_{\xi}\lVert g(\mathbf{w},\xi)-\nabla C(\mathbf{w})\rVert^{2}=d\sigma^{2}(\mathbf{w}), and the stochastic rounding function Qqsubscript𝑄𝑞Q_{q} is given in (9), the following holds,

where (39) follows from the triangle inequality and (40) follows form (38). ∎

As discussed in Section IV, Byzantine users can manipulate the training protocol via two means, either by modifying their local update (directly or by modifying the local dataset), or by sharing false information during protocol execution. In this section, we demonstrate how BREA provides robustness in both cases. We first focus on the former case and study the resilience of the global model, i.e., conditions under which the trained model remains close to the true model, even if some users modify their local updates adversarially. The second case, i.e., robustness of the protocol when some users exchange false information during the protocol execution, will be considered in Theorem 1.

In order to evaluate the resilience of the global model against Byzantine adversaries, we adopt the notion of (α,A)𝛼𝐴(\alpha,A)-Byzantine resilience from [39].

Definition 1 ((α,A)𝛼𝐴(\alpha,A)-Byzantine resilience, [39]).

Let 0≤α<π/20𝛼𝜋20\leq\alpha<\pi/2 be any angular value and 0≤A≤N0𝐴𝑁0\leq A\leq N be any integer. Let 𝐰1,…,𝐰N∈ℝdsubscript𝐰1…subscript𝐰𝑁superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbf{w}_{1},\ldots,\mathbf{w}_{N}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} be any i.i.d random vectors such that 𝐰i∼𝐰similar-tosubscript𝐰𝑖𝐰\mathbf{w}_{i}\sim\mathbf{w} with 𝔼​[𝐰]=𝐖𝔼delimited-[]𝐰𝐖\mathbb{E}[\mathbf{w}]=\mathbf{W}. Let 𝐛1,…,𝐛A∈ℝdsubscript𝐛1…subscript𝐛𝐴superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbf{b}_{1},\ldots,\mathbf{b}_{A}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} be any random vectors. Then, function f𝑓f is (α,A)𝛼𝐴(\alpha,A)-Byzantine resilient if, for any 1≤j1<⋯<jA≤N1subscript𝑗1⋯subscript𝑗𝐴𝑁1\leq j_{1}<\cdots<j_{A}\leq N,

𝐟:=f​(𝐰1,…,𝐛1⏟j1,…,𝐛A⏟jA,…,𝐰N)assign𝐟𝑓subscript𝐰1…subscript⏟subscript𝐛1subscript𝑗1…subscript⏟subscript𝐛𝐴subscript𝑗𝐴…subscript𝐰𝑁\mathbf{f}:=f\big{(}\mathbf{w}_{1},\ldots,\underbrace{\mathbf{b}_{1}}_{j_{1}},\ldots,\underbrace{\mathbf{b}_{A}}_{j_{A}},\ldots,\mathbf{w}_{N}\big{)} (41)

satisfies, i) 𝐖⊤​𝔼​[𝐟]≥(1−sin⁡α)​∥𝐖∥2superscript𝐖top𝔼delimited-[]𝐟1𝛼superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝐖2\mathbf{W}^{\top}\mathbb{E}[\mathbf{f}]\geq(1-\sin\alpha)\lVert\mathbf{W}\rVert^{2}, and ii) for r∈{2,3,4}𝑟234r\in\{2,3,4\}, 𝔼​∥𝐟∥r𝔼superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝐟𝑟\mathbb{E}\lVert\mathbf{f}\rVert^{r} is bounded above by 𝔼​∥𝐟∥r≤K​∑r1+⋯+rN−A=r𝔼​∥𝐖∥r1​…​𝔼​∥𝐖∥rN−A𝔼superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝐟𝑟𝐾subscriptsubscript𝑟1⋯subscript𝑟𝑁𝐴𝑟𝔼superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝐖subscript𝑟1…𝔼superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝐖subscript𝑟𝑁𝐴\mathbb{E}\lVert\mathbf{f}\rVert^{r}\leq K\sum_{r_{1}+\cdots+r_{N-A}=r}\mathbb{E}\lVert\mathbf{W}\rVert^{r_{1}}\ldots\mathbb{E}\lVert\mathbf{W}\rVert^{r_{N-A}} where K𝐾K denotes a generic constant.

Lemma 2 below states that if the standard deviation caused by random sample selection and quantization is smaller than the norm of the true gradient, and 2​A+2<N−m2𝐴2𝑁𝑚2A+2<N-m, then the aggregation function f𝑓f from (32) is (α,A)𝛼𝐴(\alpha,A)-Byzantine resilient where α𝛼\alpha depends on the ratio of the standard deviation over the norm of the gradient [39].

Lemma 2.

Assume that 2​A+2<N−m2𝐴2𝑁𝑚2A+2<N-m and η​(N,A)​d​σ′<∥∇C​(𝐰)∥𝜂𝑁𝐴𝑑superscript𝜎′delimited-∥∥∇𝐶𝐰\eta(N,A)\sqrt{d}\sigma^{\prime}<\lVert\nabla C(\mathbf{w})\rVert where

η​(N,A):=2​(N−A+A​(N−A−2)+A2​(N−A−1)N−2​A−2).assign𝜂𝑁𝐴2𝑁𝐴𝐴𝑁𝐴2superscript𝐴2𝑁𝐴1𝑁2𝐴2\eta(N,A):=\sqrt{2\Big{(}N-A+\frac{A(N-A-2)+A^{2}(N-A-1)}{N-2A-2}\Big{)}}. (42)

Let 𝐰1,…,𝐰Nsubscript𝐰1…subscript𝐰𝑁\mathbf{w}_{1},\ldots,\mathbf{w}_{N} be i.i.d. random vectors in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d} such that 𝐰i∼𝐰similar-tosubscript𝐰𝑖𝐰\mathbf{w}_{i}\sim\mathbf{w} with 𝔼ξ​[g​(𝐰,ξ)]=∇C​(𝐰)subscript𝔼𝜉delimited-[]𝑔𝐰𝜉∇𝐶𝐰\mathbb{E}_{\xi}[g(\mathbf{w},\xi)]=\nabla C(\mathbf{w}) and 𝔼ξ​∥g​(𝐰,ξ)−∇C​(𝐰)∥2=d​σ2​(𝐰)subscript𝔼𝜉superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑔𝐰𝜉∇𝐶𝐰2𝑑superscript𝜎2𝐰\mathbb{E}_{\xi}\lVert g(\mathbf{w},\xi)-\nabla C(\mathbf{w})\rVert^{2}=d\sigma^{2}(\mathbf{w}). Then, the aggregation function f𝑓f from (32) is (α,A)𝛼𝐴(\alpha,A)-Byzantine resilient where 0≤α<π/20𝛼𝜋20\leq\alpha<\pi/2 is defined by sin⁡α=η​(N,A)​d​σ′∥∇C​(𝐰)∥𝛼𝜂𝑁𝐴𝑑superscript𝜎′delimited-∥∥∇𝐶𝐰\sin{\alpha}=\frac{\eta(N,A)\sqrt{d}\sigma^{\prime}}{\lVert\nabla C(\mathbf{w})\rVert}.

Proof.

From Lemma 1, 𝔼Q,ξ​[Qq​(g​(𝐰,ξ))]=∇C​(𝐰)subscript𝔼𝑄𝜉delimited-[]subscript𝑄𝑞𝑔𝐰𝜉∇𝐶𝐰\mathbb{E}_{Q,\xi}[Q_{q}(g(\mathbf{w},\xi))]=\nabla C(\mathbf{w}) and 𝔼Q,ξ​∥Qq​(g​(𝐰,ξ))−∇C​(𝐰)∥2≤d​σ′⁣ 2​(𝐰)subscript𝔼𝑄𝜉superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝑄𝑞𝑔𝐰𝜉∇𝐶𝐰2𝑑superscript𝜎′2𝐰\mathbb{E}_{Q,\xi}\lVert Q_{q}(g(\mathbf{w},\xi))-\nabla C(\mathbf{w})\rVert^{2}\leq d\sigma^{\prime\;2}(\mathbf{w}). Then, the quantized multi-Krum algorithm described in Section V-D, where the multi-Krum algorithm applied to the quantized vectors Qq​(𝐰i)subscript𝑄𝑞subscript𝐰𝑖Q_{q}(\mathbf{w}_{i}), is (α,A)𝛼𝐴(\alpha,A)-Byzantine resilient from Proposition 333 of [39]. Hence, function f𝑓f in (32) is (α,A)𝛼𝐴(\alpha,A)-Byzantine resilient. ∎

We now state our main result for the theoretical performance guarantees of BREA.

Theorem 1.

We assume that: 1) the cost function C𝐶C is three times differentiable with continuous derivatives, and is bounded from below, i.e., C​(x)≥0𝐶𝑥0C(x)\geq 0; 2) the learning rates satisfy, ∑t=1∞γ(t)=∞superscriptsubscript𝑡1superscript𝛾𝑡\sum_{t=1}^{\infty}\gamma^{(t)}=\infty and ∑t=1∞(γ(t))2<∞superscriptsubscript𝑡1superscriptsuperscript𝛾𝑡2\sum_{t=1}^{\infty}({\gamma^{(t)}})^{2}<\infty; 3) the second, third, and fourth moments of the quantized gradient estimator do not grow too fast with the norm of the model, i.e., ∀r∈2,3,4for-all𝑟234\forall r\in{2,3,4}, 𝔼Q,ξ​∥Qq​(g​(𝐰,ξ))∥r≤Ar+Br​∥𝐰∥rsubscript𝔼𝑄𝜉superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝑄𝑞𝑔𝐰𝜉𝑟subscript𝐴𝑟subscript𝐵𝑟superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝐰𝑟\mathbb{E}_{Q,\xi}\lVert Q_{q}(g(\mathbf{w},\xi))\rVert^{r}\leq A_{r}+B_{r}\lVert\mathbf{w}\rVert^{r} for some constants Arsubscript𝐴𝑟A_{r} and Brsubscript𝐵𝑟B_{r}; 4) there exist a constant 0≤α<π/20𝛼𝜋20\leq\alpha<\pi/2 such that for all 𝐰∈ℝd𝐰superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbf{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, η​(N,A)​d​σ′​(𝐰)≤∥∇C​(𝐰)∥​sin⁡α𝜂𝑁𝐴𝑑superscript𝜎′𝐰delimited-∥∥∇𝐶𝐰𝛼\eta(N,A)\sqrt{d}\sigma^{\prime}(\mathbf{w})\leq\lVert\nabla C(\mathbf{w})\rVert\sin{\alpha}; 5) the gradient of the cost function C𝐶C satisfies that for ∥𝐰∥2≥Rsuperscriptdelimited-∥∥𝐰2𝑅\lVert\mathbf{w}\rVert^{2}\geq R, there exist constants ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0 and 0≤β<π/2−α0𝛽𝜋2𝛼0\leq\beta<\pi/2-\alpha such that

∥∇C​(𝐰)∥≥ϵ>0,delimited-∥∥∇𝐶𝐰italic-ϵ0\displaystyle\lVert\nabla C(\mathbf{w})\rVert\geq\epsilon>0, (43)
𝐰⊤​C​(𝐰)∥𝐰∥⋅∥∇C​(𝐰)∥≥cos⁡β.superscript𝐰top𝐶𝐰⋅delimited-∥∥𝐰delimited-∥∥∇𝐶𝐰𝛽\displaystyle\frac{\mathbf{w}^{\top}C(\mathbf{w})}{\lVert\mathbf{w}\rVert\cdot\lVert\nabla C(\mathbf{w})\rVert}\geq\cos{\beta}. (44)

Then, BREA guarantees,

  • •

    (Robustness against Byzantine users) The protocol executes correctly against up to A𝐴A Byzantine users and the trained model is (α,A)𝛼𝐴(\alpha,A)-Byzantine resilient.

  • •

    (Convergence) The sequence of the gradients ∇C​(𝐰(t))∇𝐶superscript𝐰𝑡\nabla C(\mathbf{w}^{(t)}) converges almost surely to zero,

    ∇C​(𝐰(t))→t→∞a.s.0.\nabla C(\mathbf{w}^{(t)})\xrightarrow[t\to\infty]{a.s.}0. (45)
  • •

    (Privacy) The server or any group of up to T𝑇T users cannot compute an unknown local update. For any set of users 𝒯⊂[N]𝒯delimited-[]𝑁\mathcal{T}\subset[N] of size at most T𝑇T,

    ℙ​[User i has secret 𝐰¯i∣view𝒯]ℙdelimited-[]conditionalUser i has secret 𝐰¯isubscriptview𝒯\displaystyle\mathbb{P}[\text{User $i$ has secret $\overline{\mathbf{w}}_{i}$}\mid\text{view}_{\mathcal{T}}]
    =ℙ​[User i has secret 𝐰¯i]absentℙdelimited-[]User i has secret 𝐰¯i\displaystyle\hskip 56.9055pt=\mathbb{P}[\text{User $i$ has secret $\overline{\mathbf{w}}_{i}$}] (46)

    for all i∈[N]∖𝒯𝑖delimited-[]𝑁𝒯i\in[N]\setminus\mathcal{T} where view𝒯subscriptview𝒯\text{view}_{\mathcal{T}} denotes the messages that the members of 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} receive.

for any N≥2​A+1+max⁡{m+2,D+2​T}𝑁2𝐴1𝑚2𝐷2𝑇N\geq 2A+1+\max\{m+2,D+2T\}, where m𝑚m is the number of selected models for aggregation.

Remark 1.

The two conditions ∑t=1∞γ(t)=∞superscriptsubscript𝑡1superscript𝛾𝑡\sum_{t=1}^{\infty}\gamma^{(t)}=\infty and ∑t=1∞(γ(t))2<∞superscriptsubscript𝑡1superscriptsuperscript𝛾𝑡2\sum_{t=1}^{\infty}({\gamma^{(t)}})^{2}<\infty are instrumental in the convergence of stochastic gradient descent algorithms [41]. Condition ∑t=1∞(γ(t))2<∞superscriptsubscript𝑡1superscriptsuperscript𝛾𝑡2\sum_{t=1}^{\infty}({\gamma^{(t)}})^{2}<\infty states that the learning rates decrease fast enough, whereas condition ∑t=1∞γ(t)=∞superscriptsubscript𝑡1superscript𝛾𝑡\sum_{t=1}^{\infty}\gamma^{(t)}=\infty bounds the rate of their decrease, to ensure that the learning rates do not decrease too fast.

Remark 2.

We consider a general (possibly non-convex) objective function C𝐶C. In such scenarios, proving the convergence of the model directly is challenging, and various approaches have been proposed instead. Our approach follows [41] and [10], where we prove the convergence of the gradient to a flat region instead. We note, however, that such a region may refer to any stationary point, including the local minima as well as saddle and extremal points.

Proof.

(Robustness against Byzantine users) The (α,A)𝛼𝐴(\alpha,A)-Byzantine resilience of the trained model follows from Lemma 2. We next provide sufficient conditions for BREA to correctly evaluate the update function (32), in the presence of A𝐴A Byzantine users. Byzantine users may send any arbitrary random vector to the server or other users in every step of the protocol in Section V. In particular, Byzantine users can create and send incorrect computations in three attack scenarios: i) sending invalid secret shares 𝐬i​jsubscript𝐬𝑖𝑗\mathbf{s}_{ij} in (13), ii) sending incorrect secure distance computations dj​k(i)superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑗𝑘𝑖d_{jk}^{(i)} in (16), and iii) sending incorrect aggregate of the secret shares 𝐬isubscript𝐬𝑖\mathbf{s}_{i} in (26).

The first attack scenario occurs when the secret shares 𝐬i​jsubscript𝐬𝑖𝑗\mathbf{s}_{ij} in (13) do not refer to the same polynomial from (12). BREA utilizes verifiable secret sharing to prevent such attempts. The correctness (validity) of the secret shares can be verified by testing (15), whenever the majority of the surviving users are honest, i.e., N>2​A+D𝑁2𝐴𝐷N>2A+D [18, 37].

The second attack scenario can be detected and corrected by the Reed-Solomon decoding algorithm. In particular, as described in Section V-D, given j,k∈[N]𝑗𝑘delimited-[]𝑁j,k\in[N], {dj​k(i)}i∈[N]subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑑𝑗𝑘𝑖𝑖delimited-[]𝑁\{d_{jk}^{(i)}\}_{i\in[N]} can be viewed as N𝑁N evaluation points of the polynomial hj​ksubscriptℎ𝑗𝑘h_{jk} given in (17) whose degree is at most 2​T2𝑇2T. The decoding process at the server then corresponds to the decoding of an [N,2​T+1,N−2​T]psubscript𝑁2𝑇1𝑁2𝑇𝑝[N,2T+1,N-2T]_{p} Reed-Solomon code with at most D𝐷D erasures and at most A𝐴A errors. As an [n,k,n−k+1]psubscript𝑛𝑘𝑛𝑘1𝑝[n,k,n-k+1]_{p} Reed-Solomon code with e𝑒e erasures can tolerate a maximum number of ⌊n−k−e2⌋𝑛𝑘𝑒2\lfloor\frac{n-k-e}{2}\rfloor errors [40], the server can recover the correct pairwise distances as long as A≤⌊N−(2​T+1)−D2⌋𝐴𝑁2𝑇1𝐷2A\leq\lfloor\frac{N-(2T+1)-D}{2}\rfloor, i.e. N≥D+2​A+2​T+1𝑁𝐷2𝐴2𝑇1N\geq D+2A+2T+1.

The third attack scenario can also be detected and corrected by the Reed-Solomon decoding algorithm. As described in Section V-E, {𝐬i}i∈[N]subscriptsubscript𝐬𝑖𝑖delimited-[]𝑁\{\mathbf{s}_{i}\}_{i\in[N]} are evaluation points of polynomial hℎh in (27) of degree at most T𝑇T. This decoding process corresponds to the decoding of an [N,T+1,N−T]psubscript𝑁𝑇1𝑁𝑇𝑝[N,T+1,N-T]_{p} Reed-Solomon code with at most D𝐷D erasures and at most A𝐴A errors. As such, the server can recover the desired aggregate model h​(0)=∑j∈𝒮𝐰¯jℎ0subscript𝑗𝒮subscript¯𝐰𝑗h(0)=\sum_{j\in{\mathcal{S}}}\overline{\mathbf{w}}_{j} as long as N≥D+2​A+T+1𝑁𝐷2𝐴𝑇1N\geq D+2A+T+1. Therefore, combining with the condition of Lemma 2, the sufficient conditions under which BREA guarantees robustness against Byzantine users is given by

N≥2​A+1+max⁡{m+2,D+2​T}.𝑁2𝐴1𝑚2𝐷2𝑇N\geq 2A+1+\max\{m+2,D+2T\}. (47)

(Convergence) We now consider the update equation in (32) and prove the convergence of the random sequence ∇C​(𝐰(t))∇𝐶superscript𝐰𝑡\nabla C(\mathbf{w}^{(t)}). From Lemma 2, the quantized multi-Krum function f𝑓f in (32) is (α,A)𝛼𝐴(\alpha,A)-Byzantine resilient. Hence, from Proposition 222 of [39], ∇C​(𝐰(t))∇𝐶superscript𝐰𝑡\nabla C(\mathbf{w}^{(t)}) converges almost surely to zero,

∇C​(𝐰(t))→t→∞a.s.0.\nabla C(\mathbf{w}^{(t)})\xrightarrow[t\to\infty]{a.s.}0. (48)

(Privacy) As described in Section V-B, we assume the intractability of computing discrete logarithms, hence the server or any user cannot compute 𝐰¯isubscript¯𝐰𝑖\overline{\mathbf{w}}_{i} from 𝐜i​0subscript𝐜𝑖0\mathbf{c}_{i0} in (14). It is therefore sufficient to prove the privacy of each individual model against a group of T𝑇T colluding users, in the case where 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} has size T𝑇T. If T𝑇T users cannot get any information about 𝐰¯isubscript¯𝐰𝑖\overline{\mathbf{w}}_{i}, then neither can fewer than T𝑇T users. Without loss of generality, let 𝒯={1,…,T}=[T]𝒯1…𝑇delimited-[]𝑇\mathcal{T}=\{1,\ldots,T\}=[T] and view𝒯={(𝐬k​j)k∈[N],(dk​lj)k,l∈[N],𝐬j}j∈[T]subscriptview𝒯subscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐬𝑘𝑗𝑘delimited-[]𝑁subscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑑𝑗𝑘𝑙𝑘𝑙delimited-[]𝑁subscript𝐬𝑗𝑗delimited-[]𝑇\text{view}_{\mathcal{T}}=\big{\{}(\mathbf{s}_{kj})_{k\in[N]},\big{(}d^{j}_{kl}\big{)}_{k,l\in[N]},\mathbf{s}_{j}\big{\}}_{j\in[T]} where 𝐬k​jsubscript𝐬𝑘𝑗\mathbf{s}_{kj} in (13) is the secret share of 𝐰¯ksubscript¯𝐰𝑘\overline{\mathbf{w}}_{k} sent from user k𝑘k to user j𝑗j, dk​ljsubscriptsuperscript𝑑𝑗𝑘𝑙d^{j}_{kl} in (16) is the pairwise distance of the secret shares sent from users k𝑘k and l𝑙l to user j𝑗j, and 𝐬jsubscript𝐬𝑗\mathbf{s}_{j} in (26) is the aggregate of the secret shares. As {(dk​lj)k,l∈[N]}j∈[T]subscriptsubscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑑𝑗𝑘𝑙𝑘𝑙delimited-[]𝑁𝑗delimited-[]𝑇\big{\{}\big{(}d^{j}_{kl}\big{)}_{k,l\in[N]}\big{\}}_{j\in[T]} and {𝐬j}j∈[T]subscriptsubscript𝐬𝑗𝑗delimited-[]𝑇\big{\{}\mathbf{s}_{j}\big{\}}_{j\in[T]} are determined by {(𝐬k​j)k,l∈[N]}j∈[T]subscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐬𝑘𝑗𝑘𝑙delimited-[]𝑁𝑗delimited-[]𝑇\big{\{}\big{(}\mathbf{s}_{kj}\big{)}_{k,l\in[N]}\big{\}}_{j\in[T]}, we can simplify the left hand side (LHS) of (46) as

VI-A Complexity Analysis

In this section, we analyze the complexity of BREA with respect to the number of users, N𝑁N, and model dimension d𝑑d.

Complexity Analysis of the Users: User i𝑖i’s computation cost can be broken into three parts: 1) generating the secret shares 𝐬i​jsubscript𝐬𝑖𝑗\mathbf{s}_{ij} in (12) for j∈[N]𝑗delimited-[]𝑁j\in[N], 2) computing the pairwise distances dj​k(i)subscriptsuperscript𝑑𝑖𝑗𝑘d^{(i)}_{jk} in (16) for j,k∈[N]𝑗𝑘delimited-[]𝑁j,k\in[N], and 3) aggregating the secret shares belonging to the selected users from (26). First, generating N𝑁N secret shares of a vector with dimension d𝑑d has a computation cost of O​(d​N​log2⁡N)𝑂𝑑𝑁superscript2𝑁O(dN\log^{2}N) [19]. Second, as there are O​(N2)𝑂superscript𝑁2O(N^{2}) pairwise distances, computing the pairwise distances has a computation cost of O​(d​N2)𝑂𝑑superscript𝑁2O(dN^{2}) in total. Third, when the number of selected users m=|𝒮|𝑚𝒮m=|\mathcal{S}| is O​(N)𝑂𝑁O(N), aggregating the secret shares belonging to the selected users has a computation cost of O​(d​N)𝑂𝑑𝑁O(dN). Therefore, the overall computation cost of each user is O​(d​N​log2⁡N+d​N2)𝑂𝑑𝑁superscript2𝑁𝑑superscript𝑁2O(dN\log^{2}N+dN^{2}).

User i𝑖i’s communication cost can be broken to three parts: 1) sending the secret share 𝐬i​jsubscript𝐬𝑖𝑗\mathbf{s}_{ij} to user j∈[N]𝑗delimited-[]𝑁j\in[N], 2) sending the secret shares of the pairwise distances dj​k(i)subscriptsuperscript𝑑𝑖𝑗𝑘d^{(i)}_{jk} to the server for j,k∈[N]𝑗𝑘delimited-[]𝑁j,k\in[N], and 3) sending the aggregate of secret the shares 𝐬isubscript𝐬𝑖\mathbf{s}_{i} in (26) to the server. The communication cost of the three parts are O​(d​N)𝑂𝑑𝑁O(dN), O​(N2)𝑂superscript𝑁2O(N^{2}), and O​(d)𝑂𝑑O(d), respectively. Therefore, the overall communication cost of each user is O​(d​N+N2)𝑂𝑑𝑁superscript𝑁2O(dN+N^{2}).

Complexity Analysis of the Server: Computation cost of the server can be broken into three parts: 1) decoding the pairwise distances by recovering hj​k​(0)subscriptℎ𝑗𝑘0h_{jk}(0) in (17) for j,k∈[N]𝑗𝑘delimited-[]𝑁j,k\in[N], 2) carrying out the multi-Krum algorithm to select the m𝑚m users for aggregation, and 3) decoding the aggregate of the selected models by recovering h​(0)ℎ0h(0) in (27). As described in Section V-D, recovering the polynomial hj​ksubscriptℎ𝑗𝑘h_{jk} corresponds to decoding an [N,2​T+1,N−2​T]psubscript𝑁2𝑇1𝑁2𝑇𝑝[N,2T+1,N-2T]_{p} Reed-Solomon code with at most D𝐷D erasures and at most A𝐴A errors, which has an O​(N​log2⁡N​log⁡log⁡N)𝑂𝑁superscript2𝑁𝑁O(N\log^{2}N\log\log N) computation cost [40]. As there are O​(N2)𝑂superscript𝑁2O(N^{2}) pairs and each pair is embedded in a single polynomial, the computation cost of the first part is O​(N3​log2⁡N​log⁡log⁡N)𝑂superscript𝑁3superscript2𝑁𝑁O(N^{3}\log^{2}N\log\log N) in total. The computation cost of the second part is O​(d​N2+N2​log⁡N)𝑂𝑑superscript𝑁2superscript𝑁2𝑁O(dN^{2}+N^{2}\log N) [10]. As the dimension of h​(0)ℎ0h(0) is d𝑑d, the computation cost of the third part is O​(d​N​log2⁡N​log⁡log⁡N)𝑂𝑑𝑁superscript2𝑁𝑁O(dN\log^{2}N\log\log N). Overall, the computation cost of the server is O​((N3+d​N)​log2⁡N​log⁡log⁡N)𝑂superscript𝑁3𝑑𝑁superscript2𝑁𝑁O((N^{3}+dN)\log^{2}N\log\log{N}).

Communication cost can be broken into two parts: 1) receiving the secret shares of the pairwise distances dj​k(i)subscriptsuperscript𝑑𝑖𝑗𝑘d^{(i)}_{jk} from users i∈[N]𝑖delimited-[]𝑁i\in[N] for j,k∈[N]𝑗𝑘delimited-[]𝑁j,k\in[N] and 2) receiving the aggregate of secret shared models 𝐬isubscript𝐬𝑖\mathbf{s}_{i} from users i∈[N]𝑖delimited-[]𝑁i\in[N]. The communication cost of the two parts are O​(N3)𝑂superscript𝑁3O(N^{3}) and O​(d​N)𝑂𝑑𝑁O(dN), respectively. Overall, the communication cost of the server is O​(d​N+N3)𝑂𝑑𝑁superscript𝑁3O(dN+N^{3}).

We summarize the complexity analysis in Table I. As can be observed in Table I, the server has a communication cost of O​(N3)𝑂superscript𝑁3O(N^{3}) and a computation cost of O​(N3​log2⁡N​log⁡log⁡N)𝑂superscript𝑁3superscript2𝑁𝑁O(N^{3}\log^{2}{N}\log\log{N}), which is due to the recovery of N2superscript𝑁2N^{2} pairwise distances. Although the distances are scalar valued, the overhead can become a limitation for very large-scale networks. In the next subsection, we propose a generalized framework to reduce the communication cost from O​(N3)𝑂superscript𝑁3O(N^{3}) to O​(N2)𝑂superscript𝑁2O(N^{2}) as well as to reduce the computation cost from O​(N3​log2⁡N​log⁡log⁡N)𝑂superscript𝑁3superscript2𝑁𝑁O(N^{3}\log^{2}{N}\log\log{N}) to O​(N2​log2⁡N​log⁡log⁡N)𝑂superscript𝑁2superscript2𝑁𝑁O(N^{2}\log^{2}{N}\log\log{N}).

VI-B The Generalized BREA Framework

The key idea of the generalized framework is to partition the set of N​(N−1)/2𝑁𝑁12N(N-1)/2 pairwise distances into sets of size K𝐾K, and embed the K𝐾K distances in a single polynomial. Consequently, the number of polynomials to embed the N​(N−1)/2𝑁𝑁12N(N-1)/2 pairwise distances can be reduced from O​(N2)𝑂superscript𝑁2O(N^{2}) to O​(N2/K)𝑂superscript𝑁2𝐾O(N^{2}/K). Each user then sends a single evaluation point of each polynomial to the server, which has an O​(N3/K)𝑂superscript𝑁3𝐾O(N^{3}/K) communication cost in total. By setting K=O​(N)𝐾𝑂𝑁K=O(N), the generalized BREA framework can achieve O​(N2)𝑂superscript𝑁2O(N^{2}) communication complexity.

We now present the details of the generalized BREA framework. In the stochastic quantization phase, the generalized BREA framework follows the same steps as in Section V-A. In the verifiable secret sharing phase, user i∈[N]𝑖delimited-[]𝑁i\in[N] generates secret shares of the quantized model 𝐰¯isubscript¯𝐰𝑖\overline{\mathbf{w}}_{i} by modifying the random polynomial fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} in (12) as,

fi​(θ)=𝐰¯i+∑j=1T𝐫i​j​θK+j−1subscript𝑓𝑖𝜃subscript¯𝐰𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑇subscript𝐫𝑖𝑗superscript𝜃𝐾𝑗1f_{i}(\theta)=\overline{\mathbf{w}}_{i}+\sum_{j=1}^{T}\mathbf{r}_{ij}\theta^{K+j-1} (52)

where the degree of fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} is increased from T𝑇T to K+T−1𝐾𝑇1K+T-1. User i𝑖i then sends a secret share of 𝐰¯isubscript¯𝐰𝑖\overline{\mathbf{w}}_{i} to user j∈[N]𝑗delimited-[]𝑁j\in[N], denoted by 𝐬i​j=fi​(θj)subscript𝐬𝑖𝑗subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝜃𝑗\mathbf{s}_{ij}=f_{i}(\theta_{j}).

In the secure distance computation phase, user i𝑖i computes the pairwise distances dj​k(i)superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑗𝑘𝑖d_{jk}^{(i)} as in (16) for j,k∈[N]𝑗𝑘delimited-[]𝑁j,k\in[N]. Note that there are N​(N−1)2𝑁𝑁12\frac{N(N-1)}{2} unique distance values, due to the symmetry of the distance measure. The server and the users then agree on a partition 𝒫1,…,𝒫Gsubscript𝒫1…subscript𝒫𝐺\mathcal{P}_{1},\ldots,\mathcal{P}_{G} of the N​(N−1)2𝑁𝑁12\frac{N(N-1)}{2} distances into sets of size K𝐾K, where G=⌈N​(N−1)2​K⌉𝐺𝑁𝑁12𝐾G=\lceil\frac{N(N-1)}{2K}\rceil and |𝒫k|=Ksubscript𝒫𝑘𝐾|\mathcal{P}_{k}|=K for all k∈[G]𝑘delimited-[]𝐺k\in[G]. ⌈x⌉𝑥\lceil x\rceil denotes the smallest integer greater or equal to x𝑥x. Then, each user embeds the K𝐾K pairwise distances in each 𝒫ksubscript𝒫𝑘\mathcal{P}_{k} into a single polynomial, for every k∈{1,…,G}𝑘1…𝐺k\in\{1,\ldots,G\}. For instance, let the first set in the partition be 𝒫1={(1,2),…,(1,K+1)}subscript𝒫112…1𝐾1\mathcal{P}_{1}=\{(1,2),\ldots,(1,K+1)\}, Then, one can define a univariate polynomial u𝒫1:𝔽p→𝔽p:subscript𝑢subscript𝒫1→subscript𝔽𝑝subscript𝔽𝑝{u}_{\mathcal{P}_{1}}:\mathbb{F}_{p}\rightarrow\mathbb{F}_{p} of degree 2​(K+T−1)+K−12𝐾𝑇1𝐾12(K+T-1)+K-1 to embed the K𝐾K pairwise distances of the pairs in 𝒫1subscript𝒫1\mathcal{P}_{1} as

u𝒫1​(θ)subscript𝑢subscript𝒫1𝜃\displaystyle{u}_{\mathcal{P}_{1}}(\theta) =∥𝐟1​(θ)−𝐟2​(θ)∥2+θ​∥𝐟1​(θ)−𝐟3​(θ)∥2absentsuperscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝐟1𝜃subscript𝐟2𝜃2𝜃superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝐟1𝜃subscript𝐟3𝜃2\displaystyle=\lVert\mathbf{f}_{1}(\theta)-\mathbf{f}_{2}(\theta)\rVert^{2}+\theta\lVert\mathbf{f}_{1}(\theta)-\mathbf{f}_{3}(\theta)\rVert^{2}
+⋯+θK−1​∥𝐟1​(θ)−𝐟K+1​(θ)∥2.⋯superscript𝜃𝐾1superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝐟1𝜃subscript𝐟𝐾1𝜃2\displaystyle\quad+\cdots+\theta^{K-1}\lVert\mathbf{f}_{1}(\theta)-\mathbf{f}_{K+1}(\theta)\rVert^{2}. (53)

As the coefficients from the first degree to the (K−1)𝐾1(K-1)-th degree terms in (52) are zero, the coefficient of the (k−1)𝑘1(k-1)-th degree term in (53) corresponds to the pairwise distance of the k𝑘k-th pair in 𝒫1subscript𝒫1\mathcal{P}_{1}, i.e., ∥𝐟1​(0)−𝐟k+1​(0)∥2=∥𝐰¯1−𝐰¯k+1∥2superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝐟10subscript𝐟𝑘102superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript¯𝐰1subscript¯𝐰𝑘12\lVert\mathbf{f}_{1}(0)-\mathbf{f}_{k+1}(0)\rVert^{2}=\lVert\overline{\mathbf{w}}_{1}-\overline{\mathbf{w}}_{k+1}\rVert^{2} for all k∈[K]𝑘delimited-[]𝐾k\in[K]. User i𝑖i then sends u𝒫1​(θi)subscript𝑢subscript𝒫1subscript𝜃𝑖{u}_{\mathcal{P}_{1}}(\theta_{i}) to the server. Upon receiving the computation results from a sufficient number of users, the server can decode the pairwise distances of all pairs in 𝒫1subscript𝒫1\mathcal{P}_{1} by reconstructing the polynomial u𝒫1​(θi)subscript𝑢subscript𝒫1subscript𝜃𝑖{u}_{\mathcal{P}_{1}}(\theta_{i}). As the degree of u𝒫1subscript𝑢subscript𝒫1{u}_{\mathcal{P}_{1}} is 3​K+2​T−33𝐾2𝑇33K+2T-3, the minimum number of results the server needs to collect from the users to recover the pairwise distances, i.e., the recovery threshold, is 3​K+2​T−23𝐾2𝑇23K+2T-2. The decoding process of the polynomial corresponds to decoding an [N,3​K+2​T−3,N−3​K−2​T+2]psubscript𝑁3𝐾2𝑇3𝑁3𝐾2𝑇2𝑝[N,3K+2T-3,N-3K-2T+2]_{p} Reed-Solomon code with at most D𝐷D erasures and at most A𝐴A errors. In a similar way, we can define polynomials u𝒫ksubscript𝑢subscript𝒫𝑘{u}_{\mathcal{P}_{k}} for k∈{2,…,G}𝑘2…𝐺k\in\{2,\ldots,G\} where user i𝑖i computes and sends u𝒫k​(θi)subscript𝑢subscript𝒫𝑘subscript𝜃𝑖{u}_{\mathcal{P}_{k}}(\theta_{i}) to the server. The server can then decode all of the N​(N−1)/2𝑁𝑁12N(N-1)/2 pairwise distances by reconstructing the G𝐺G polynomials.

After the server learns the pairwise distances, the generalized protocol follows the same steps as in Sections V-D and V-E. The overall algorithm of the generalized BREA framework is presented in Algorithm 2.

The generalized BREA framework achieves a communication cost of O​(N2)𝑂superscript𝑁2O(N^{2}) and computation cost of O​(N2​log2⁡N​log⁡log⁡N)𝑂superscript𝑁2superscript2𝑁𝑁O(N^{2}\log^{2}{N}\log\log{N}) by setting K=O​(N)𝐾𝑂𝑁K=O(N), which follows from the following observations. First, user i𝑖i sends an evaluation point of each polynomial u𝒫ksubscript𝑢subscript𝒫𝑘u_{\mathcal{P}_{k}} to the server for k∈[G]𝑘delimited-[]𝐺k\in[G], and there are N𝑁N users and G=O​(N2/K)=O​(N)𝐺𝑂superscript𝑁2𝐾𝑂𝑁G=O(N^{2}/K)=O(N) polynomials, which has O​(N2)𝑂superscript𝑁2O(N^{2}) communication overhead in total. Second, the computation cost to decode the polynomial u𝒫ksubscript𝑢subscript𝒫𝑘u_{\mathcal{P}_{k}} is O​(N​log2⁡N​log⁡log⁡N)𝑂𝑁superscript2𝑁𝑁O(N\log^{2}{N}\log\log N) [40] and there are G=O​(N)𝐺𝑂𝑁G=O(N) polynomials, which has a computation cost of O​(N2​log2⁡N​log⁡log⁡N)𝑂superscript𝑁2superscript2𝑁𝑁O(N^{2}\log^{2}{N}\log\log N) in total. We summarize the complexity of the generalized BREA protocol in Table II.

VII Experiments

In this section, we demonstrate the convergence and resilience properties of BREA compared to conventional federated learning, i.e., the federated averaging scheme from [2], which is termed FedAvg throughout the section. We measure the performance in terms of the cross entropy loss evaluated over the training samples and the model accuracy evaluated over the test samples, with respect to the iteration index, t𝑡t.

Network architecture: We consider an image classification task with 10 classes on the MNIST dataset [42], and train a convolutional neural network with 6 layers [2] including two 5×5555\times 5 convolutional layers with stride 1, where the first and the second layers have 32 and 64 channels, respectively, and each is followed by ReLu activation and 2×2222\times 2 max pooling layer. It also includes a fully connected layer with 102410241024 units and ReLu activation followed by a final softmax output layer.

Experiment setup: We assume a network of N=40𝑁40N=40 users where T=7𝑇7T=7 users may collude and A𝐴A users are malicious. We consider two cases for the number of Byzantine users: i) 0%percent00\% Byzantine users (A=0𝐴0A=0) and ii) 30%percent3030\% Byzantine users (A=12𝐴12A=12). For i.i.d. data distribution, 600006000060000 training samples are shuffled and then partitioned into N=40𝑁40N=40 users each receiving 150015001500 samples. Honest users utilize the ADAM optimizer [43] to update the local update by setting the size of the local mini-batch sample to |ξi(t)|=500superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑖𝑡500|\xi_{i}^{(t)}|=500 for all i∈[N],t∈[J]formulae-sequence𝑖delimited-[]𝑁𝑡delimited-[]𝐽i\in[N],t\in[J] where J𝐽J is the total number of iterations. Byzantine users generate vectors uniformly at random from 𝔽pdsuperscriptsubscript𝔽𝑝𝑑\mathbb{F}_{p}^{d} where we set the field size p=232−5𝑝superscript2325p=2^{32}-5, which is the largest prime within 323232 bits. For both schemes, BREA and FedAvg, the number of models to be aggregated is set to m=|𝒮|=13<N−2​A−2𝑚𝒮13𝑁2𝐴2m=|\mathcal{S}|=13<N-2A-2. FedAvg randomly selects m𝑚m models at each iteration while BREA selects m𝑚m users from (24).

Convergence and robustness against Byzantine users: Figure 2 shows the test accuracy of BREA and FedAvg for different number of Byzantine users. We can observe that BREA with 0%percent00\% and 30%percent3030\% Byzantine users is as efficient as FedAvg with 0%percent00\% Byzantine users, while FedAvg does not tolerate Byzantine users. Figure 3 presents the cross entropy loss for BREA versus FedAvg for different number of Byzantine users. We omit the FedAvg with 30%percent3030\% Byzantine users as it diverges. We observe that BREA with 30%percent3030\% Byzantine users achieves convergence with comparable rate to FedAvg with 0%percent00\% Byzantine users, while providing robustness against Byzantine users and being privacy-preserving. For all cases of BREA in Figures 2 and 3, we set the quantization value in (9) to q=1024𝑞1024q=1024. Figure 4 further illustrates the cross entropy loss of BREA for different values of quantization parameter q𝑞q. We can observe that BREA with a larger value of q𝑞q has better performance because the variance caused by the quantization function Qqsubscript𝑄𝑞Q_{q} defined in (9) gets smaller as q𝑞q increases. On the other hand, given the field size p𝑝p, the quantization parameter q𝑞q should be less than a certain threshold to ensure (23) holds.

Non-i.i.d dataset: To investigate the performance of BREA with non-i.i.d dataset, we partition the MNIST data over N=100𝑁100N=100 users by using the same non-i.i.d setting of [2]. In this setting, 600006000060000 training samples are sorted by their digit labels and partitioned into 200200200 shards of size 300300300. Then, N=100𝑁100N=100 users are considered, where each user receives two shards with different digit labels. We assume T=20𝑇20T=20 users may collude and consider two cases for the number of Byzantine users: i) 0%percent00\% Byzantine users (A=0𝐴0A=0) and ii) 20%percent2020\% Byzantine users (A=20𝐴20A=20). Honest users utilize the ADAM optimizer to update the model by setting the size of the local mini-batch sample to |ξi(t)|=10superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑖𝑡10|\xi_{i}^{(t)}|=10 and local iterations to 555 (i.e., each user locally updates the model 555 times before sending to the server at each iteration). Byzantine users generate vectors uniformly at random from 𝔽pdsuperscriptsubscript𝔽𝑝𝑑\mathbb{F}_{p}^{d}. For both schemes, BREA and FedAvg, the number of models to be aggregated is set to m=50𝑚50m=50. Figure 5 shows the test accuracy of BREA and FedAvg for different number of Byzantine users. Even for the non-i.i.d. dataset, BREA with 0%percent00\% and 20%percent2020\% Byzantine users empirically demonstrates comparable test accuracy to FedAvg with 0%percent00\% Byzantine users.

CIFAR-10 dataset: To investigate the performance of BREA with a larger dataset, we additionally experiment with CIFAR-10 [44], by using the same model architecture of [4] (about 106superscript10610^{6} model parameters). We use the same setting for parameters N,A,m,p𝑁𝐴𝑚𝑝N,A,m,p as the setting of i.i.d MNIST dataset. Figure 6 shows that the BREA algorithm (with 30%percent3030\% Byzantine users) has comparable test accuracy to the FedAvg algorithm (with no Byzantine users).

VIII Conclusion

This paper presents the first single-server solution for Byzantine-resilient secure federated learning. Our framework is based on a verifiable secure outlier detection strategy to guarantee robustness of the trained model against Byzantine faults, while protecting the privacy of the individual users. We provide the theoretical convergence guarantees and the fundamental performance trade-offs of our framework, in terms of the number of Byzantine adversaries and the user dropouts the system can tolerate. In our experiments, we have implemented our system in a distributed network by using two ways of partitioning the MNIST dataset over up to N=100𝑁100N=100 users: i.i.d. and non-i.i.d. data distribution. For both settings, we numerically demonstrated the convergence behaviour while providing robustness against Byzantine users and being privacy-preserving. Future directions include developing single-server Byzantine-resilient secure learning architectures considering the heterogeneous environments in terms of computation and communication resources, developing efficient communication architectures, and quantization techniques.

In this paper, we utilize the distance based outlier detection approach to guarantee the robustness against Byzantine users. There have been many outlier detection approaches for Byzantine resilient SGD methods (or federated learning). Existing works can be roughly classified into two main categories: 1) geometric median [10, 11] and 2) coordinate-wise median [12, 13, 14]. Our framework utilizes the geometric median based approach because it is more efficient in the secure domain. In order to preserve the privacy of local updates, the coordinate-wise median based approaches require a multiparty secure comparison protocol [45] to find the median value of each coordinate. On the other hand, in our framework, the server compares the pairwise distances in plaintext, which is much more efficient than the secure comparison protocol. Extending the coordinate-wise median based algorithms to the secure domain would be a very interesting future direction.

-A The BREA Framework with Local Updating Schemes

In this section, we present how BREA framework can work with local updating schemes where each user locally takes multiple-steps of stochastic gradient descent using its local data before sending the updated model to server.

The BREA framework with local updating schemes follows the same steps from Section V-A to Section V-E by changing the local update 𝐰i(t)superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑖𝑡\mathbf{w}_{i}^{(t)} of user i𝑖i from a gradient estimate to the updated model by using multiple-steps of stochastic gradient descent (SGD). Then, the update equation of a benign user i𝑖i can be expressed as follows,

where 𝒥Esubscript𝒥𝐸\mathcal{J}_{E} denotes the set of global synchronization steps, i.e., 𝒥E={n​E|n=1,2,⋯}subscript𝒥𝐸conditional-set𝑛𝐸𝑛12⋯\mathcal{J}_{E}=\{nE\;|\;n=1,2,\cdots\}, E𝐸E is the number of local iterations, and 𝒮(t+1)superscript𝒮𝑡1\mathcal{S}^{(t+1)} is the index set of selected users at iteration t+1𝑡1t+1 by utilizing the multi-Krum algorithm described in Section V-D. An additional vector 𝐯i(t+1)superscriptsubscript𝐯𝑖𝑡1\mathbf{v}_{i}^{(t+1)} is introduced to represent the immediate result of one step SGD update from 𝐰i(t)superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑖𝑡\mathbf{w}_{i}^{(t)}. Malicious user i𝑖i can send any random vector 𝐛i(t+1)∈ℝdsuperscriptsubscript𝐛𝑖𝑡1superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbf{b}_{i}^{(t+1)}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, which we represent as 𝐯i(t+1)=𝐛i(t+1)superscriptsubscript𝐯𝑖𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝐛𝑖𝑡1\mathbf{v}_{i}^{(t+1)}=\mathbf{b}_{i}^{(t+1)}. We note that the distance-based outlier detection algorithm of which inputs are the local models instead of local gradient works effectively as the distance between the local models is equal to the multiplication of the learning rate γ𝛾\gamma and the distance between the local gradients. Consequently, the aggregation step at the server side can be represented as
